use_cases.title: Beginner Onboarding and Personalized Profile Setup
use_cases.description: New users complete a simplified onboarding process that creates a personalized fitness profile without overwhelming them with complex options, following the trend of simplified user experiences for fitness beginners.
use_cases.preconditions: User has downloaded and launched the app for the first time
main_flow: User opens the app and sees a welcoming, non-intimidating splash screen
User completes a brief fitness assessment (current activity level, goals, available equipment)
User selects primary fitness goals from beginner-friendly options (e.g., 'Build basic strength', 'Improve cardiovascular health')
User grants permissions for Apple Health/Google Fit integration
User sets up basic notification preferences
System creates a personalized dashboard with recommended starting plan
User is guided through a quick tutorial of core features
alternate_flows: User skips fitness assessment and uses default beginner settings
User declines health app integration and can enable it later in settings
use_cases.postconditions: User has a complete profile with personalized recommendations and understands basic app navigation
use_cases.business_value: Reduces user drop-off during critical first session by providing a welcoming, guided experience that addresses beginner intimidation

use_cases.title: Workout Plan Selection and Guided Execution
use_cases.description: Users browse and select from curated beginner workout plans, then follow guided sessions with exercise demonstrations using images/GIFs to avoid video hosting costs while maintaining quality instruction.
use_cases.preconditions: User has completed onboarding and has an active profile
main_flow: User navigates to the 'Workout Plans' section
System displays filtered recommendations based on user's goals and equipment
User browses plans with clear difficulty indicators and time commitments
User selects a plan and views detailed overview including exercises and schedule
User starts a workout session
System displays current exercise with image/GIF demonstration and simple instructions
User logs sets, reps, or duration for each exercise
System provides encouragement and form tips between exercises
User completes workout and receives summary and achievement notification
alternate_flows: User creates a custom workout by selecting individual exercises
User modifies an existing plan by swapping exercises
User pauses workout and resumes later
use_cases.postconditions: Workout data is logged, progress is updated, and user feels accomplished
use_cases.business_value: Core functionality that delivers primary value proposition of guided fitness for beginners, differentiating from complex tracking-only apps

use_cases.title: AI-Powered Nutrition Tracking via Photo Capture
use_cases.description: Users capture photos of meals which are analyzed by third-party AI API to estimate nutritional content, providing a low-friction alternative to manual calorie counting that addresses the saturated nutrition tracking market.
use_cases.preconditions: User has camera permissions enabled and is logged into the app
main_flow: User taps 'Log Meal' button on nutrition dashboard
User selects 'Take Photo' option
User captures photo of their meal
System uploads photo to third-party AI service (e.g., Google Cloud Vision API)
AI returns estimated food items and nutritional information
User reviews and confirms or adjusts the AI analysis
User can add portion size if needed
System logs meal to daily nutrition summary
User sees updated daily nutrition dashboard with visual indicators
alternate_flows: AI fails to identify food items and user manually enters meal
User uploads photo from gallery instead of taking new photo
User skips logging and returns later
use_cases.postconditions: Meal is logged with estimated nutritional data, contributing to daily nutrition tracking
use_cases.business_value: Provides innovative differentiator in crowded nutrition market by reducing friction and leveraging AI trend, potentially attracting users tired of manual logging

use_cases.title: Progress Visualization and Goal Achievement
use_cases.description: Users view comprehensive progress dashboards showing workout consistency, strength improvements, and body composition changes through simple, motivating visualizations that celebrate small wins.
use_cases.preconditions: User has logged at least one workout or measurement
main_flow: User navigates to 'Progress' section
System displays dashboard with multiple progress widgets
User views workout consistency calendar showing completed sessions
User taps on strength widget to see progression on key exercises
User views body measurement trends (weight, photos if uploaded)
System celebrates milestones and achievements with badges
User can adjust goals based on current progress
System provides personalized insights and recommendations
alternate_flows: User exports progress data for sharing with trainer
User compares current progress to previous time periods
User adds custom measurements to track
use_cases.postconditions: User understands their progress and feels motivated to continue
use_cases.business_value: Increases user retention by providing tangible evidence of improvement, addressing beginner need for positive reinforcement

use_cases.title: Private Progress Sharing with Trusted Friends
use_cases.description: Users selectively share their progress and achievements with a small, trusted group of friends, providing social motivation without the complexity and moderation overhead of public social features.
use_cases.preconditions: User has some progress data to share and has connected with at least one friend
main_flow: User navigates to 'Sharing' section
User selects 'Share Progress' option
User chooses specific achievements or milestones to share
User selects which friends to share with from their trusted list
User adds optional message of encouragement
System sends notification to selected friends
Friends can view shared progress and send reactions/encouragement
User receives notifications of friend responses
alternate_flows: User declines to share and keeps progress private
User adjusts sharing preferences for future automatic sharing
User removes friends from sharing list
use_cases.postconditions: Progress is shared with selected friends, providing social support and motivation
use_cases.business_value: Provides social motivation benefits while avoiding moderation costs and privacy concerns of public social features

use_cases.title: Health Ecosystem Data Synchronization
use_cases.description: The app seamlessly synchronizes workout and health data with Apple Health and Google Fit, meeting user expectations for integrated health tracking while leveraging existing ecosystem investments.
use_cases.preconditions: User has granted permissions for health app integration
main_flow: User completes a workout in the app
System automatically syncs workout data to connected health apps
User views workout in Apple Health/Google Fit dashboard
System imports steps, weight, and other metrics from health apps
Imported data is used to enhance progress tracking and recommendations
User can manage integration preferences in settings
System handles conflicts and data resolution transparently
alternate_flows: User revokes access for specific data types
Sync fails and system queues data for later retry
use_cases.postconditions: Data is consistently synchronized between the app and connected health ecosystems
use_cases.business_value: Meets critical user expectation for ecosystem integration, increasing app stickiness and perceived value

business_requirements.overview: A beginner-friendly fitness mobile application targeting users aged 25-45 who feel intimidated by existing fitness apps. The app will focus on simplified workout tracking, AI-powered nutrition logging via photos, and private progress sharing, built on React Native with Node.js backend and AWS infrastructure.
business_goals: Achieve 50,000 active users within 6 months of launch
Maintain user retention rate of 40% after 30 days
Convert 5-8% of free users to premium subscription
Establish the app as the go-to solution for fitness beginners in niche market
Achieve 4.5+ star rating on app stores through superior beginner experience
success_criteria: Average session duration > 10 minutes indicating engagement
Workout completion rate > 70% for started sessions
Nutrition logging frequency > 3 times per week per active user
App Store and Play Store ratings maintain 4.5+ stars
Premium subscription revenue covers 50% of operational costs within first year
constraints: Development budget limited to avoid video hosting costs in MVP
Must launch within 6-8 months to capture market opportunity
Technical stack fixed to React Native, Node.js, PostgreSQL, AWS
Initial integrations limited to Apple Health and Google Fit only
Social features restricted to private sharing to minimize moderation overhead
AI nutrition tracking dependent on third-party API reliability and costs
assumptions: Target audience (25-45 beginners) is underserved by current market offerings
AI photo recognition for food will be sufficiently accurate for MVP
Users will prefer photo-based nutrition logging over manual entry
Freemium model with $9.99/month pricing is acceptable to target market
React Native will provide adequate performance for fitness tracking features
AWS infrastructure will scale cost-effectively with user growth

risks.risk: AI nutrition recognition accuracy may lead to user frustration
risks.mitigation: Implement user feedback loop for AI corrections, provide manual entry fallback, clearly set accuracy expectations

risks.risk: Competition from established fitness apps may limit market penetration
risks.mitigation: Focus marketing on beginner pain points, emphasize simplicity, leverage niche positioning

risks.risk: Third-party API dependencies (AI, health integrations) may cause service disruptions
risks.mitigation: Implement retry mechanisms, cache critical data, have backup providers identified

risks.risk: Data privacy compliance requirements may increase development complexity
risks.mitigation: Engage legal counsel early, implement privacy-by-design principles, maintain transparent policies

risks.risk: 6-8 month timeline may be aggressive for feature set
risks.mitigation: Prioritize MVP features aggressively, be prepared to defer non-critical features, use agile methodology
